frontmatter.title: Linearly dependent list extends to a basis

mainmatter.p: Every linearly independent list of vectors in a finite-dimensional vector space can be extended to a basis.
This note introduces the concept of finite-dimensional vector space. Refer to Linear Algebra Done Right.
Adding up scalar mulitples of vectors in a list gives a linear combination.

Let VVVV be a vector space over a field FFFF. Let v_1, \dots , v_nv1,…,vnv_1, \dots , v_nv1​,…,vn​ be vectors in VVVV. A linear combination of v_1, \dots , v_nv1,…,vnv_1, \dots , v_nv1​,…,vn​ is an expression of the form a_1 v_1 + \dots + a_n v_n a1v1+⋯+anvn a_1 v_1 + \dots + a_n v_n a1​v1​+⋯+an​vn​ where a_1, \dots , a_n \in Fa1,…,an∈Fa_1, \dots , a_n \in Fa1​,…,an​∈F.
To talk about a structure, we usually define a collection of this structure. Hence we have span for linear combinations.

Let VVVV be a vector space over a field FFFF. Let v_1, \dots , v_nv1,…,vnv_1, \dots , v_nv1​,…,vn​ be vectors in VVVV. The span of v_1, \dots , v_nv1,…,vnv_1, \dots , v_nv1​,…,vn​ is defined as \text {span} (v_1, \dots , v_n) = \{ a_1 v_1 + \dots + a_n v_n \mid a_i \in F \} span(v1,…,vn)={a1v1+⋯+anvn∣ai∈F} \text {span} (v_1, \dots , v_n) = \{ a_1 v_1 + \dots + a_n v_n \mid a_i \in F \} span(v1​,…,vn​)={a1​v1​+⋯+an​vn​∣ai​∈F} The span of empty set is defined to be \{ 0 \}{0}\{ 0 \}{0}.
If \text {span} (v_1, \dots , v_n) = Vspan(v1,…,vn)=V\text {span} (v_1, \dots , v_n) = Vspan(v1​,…,vn​)=V, we say that v_1, \dots , v_nv1,…,vnv_1, \dots , v_nv1​,…,vn​ spans VVVV.

Suppose we have span S= \text {span} (v_1, \dots , v_n)S=span(v1,…,vn)S= \text {span} (v_1, \dots , v_n)S=span(v1​,…,vn​). (Span is trivially a subspace.) Obviously for all v_j (1 \leq j \leq n)vj(1≤j≤n)v_j (1 \leq j \leq n)vj​(1≤j≤n), v_j \in Svj∈Sv_j \in Svj​∈S. Because subspaces are closed under scalar multiplication and addition, every subspace of VVVV containing v_1, \dots , v_nv1,…,vnv_1, \dots , v_nv1​,…,vn​ must contain SSSS. Thus we conclude that SSSS is the smallest subspace containing v_1, \dots , v_nv1,…,vnv_1, \dots , v_nv1​,…,vn​.
The discussion about spans leads to a key definition in linear algebra.
A vector space VVVV is called finite-dimensional if some list of vectors v_1, \dots , v_nv1,…,vnv_1, \dots , v_nv1​,…,vn​ spans VVVV.
The opposite of finite-dimensional is infinite-dimensional.
A vector space VVVV is called infinite-dimensional if it is not finite-dimensional.

Consider the situation that there is only one way to express a vector vvvv as a linear combination of vectors in a list v_1, \dots , v_nv1,…,vnv_1, \dots , v_nv1​,…,vn​. What property of the list v_1, \dots , v_nv1,…,vnv_1, \dots , v_nv1​,…,vn​ does this situation imply? The answer is linear independence.

A set of vectors \{ v_1, \dots , v_n \}{v1,…,vn}\{ v_1, \dots , v_n \}{v1​,…,vn​} is called linearly independent if a_1 v_1 + \dots + a_n v_n = 0a1v1+⋯+anvn=0a_1 v_1 + \dots + a_n v_n = 0a1​v1​+⋯+an​vn​=0 implies that a_1 = \dots = a_n = 0a1=⋯=an=0a_1 = \dots = a_n = 0a1​=⋯=an​=0. The trivial case of \{ 0 \}{0}\{ 0 \}{0} is also considered linearly independent.
If some vectors are not linearly independent, then there are more than one way to express a vector as a linear combination of vectors in the list. This leads to the following definition.

A set of vectors \{ v_1, \dots , v_n \}{v1,…,vn}\{ v_1, \dots , v_n \}{v1​,…,vn​} is called linearly dependent if a_1 v_1 + \dots + a_n v_n = 0a1v1+⋯+anvn=0a_1 v_1 + \dots + a_n v_n = 0a1​v1​+⋯+an​vn​=0 for some a_1, \dots , a_n \in \mathbb {F}a1,…,an∈Fa_1, \dots , a_n \in \mathbb {F}a1​,…,an​∈F with at least one a_i \neq 0ai≠0a_i \neq 0ai​=0 (not all 0000).
The following lemma is a direct consequence of the definition of linear independence. It states that for a given linearly dependent list, we can always remove a vector without changing the span.

Let v_1, \dots , v_nv1,…,vnv_1, \dots , v_nv1​,…,vn​ be vectors in a vector space VVVV over a field \mathbb {F}F\mathbb {F}F. If v_1, \dots , v_nv1,…,vnv_1, \dots , v_nv1​,…,vn​ are linearly dependent, then there exists 1 \leq i \leq n1≤i≤n1 \leq i \leq n1≤i≤n such that v_i \in \text {span} (v_1, \dots , v_{i-1})vi∈span(v1,…,vi−1)v_i \in \text {span} (v_1, \dots , v_{i-1})vi​∈span(v1​,…,vi−1​) Remove v_iviv_ivi​ from the list v_1, \dots , v_nv1,…,vnv_1, \dots , v_nv1​,…,vn​ and the span does not change

frontmatter.title: Length of linearly independent list \leq≤\leq≤ length of spanning list

mainmatter.p: In a finite dimensional vector space, the length of a linearly independent list is less than or equal to the length of a spanning list.
We have discussed linear independent lists and spanning lists. Now we are ready to define a basis.
A basis of VVVV is a list of vectors in VVVV that is linearly independent and spans VVVV.

Criterion for basis A list of vectors \{ v_1, \dots , v_n \}{v1,…,vn}\{ v_1, \dots , v_n \}{v1​,…,vn​} is a basis of VVVV if and only if every v \in Vv∈Vv \in Vv∈V can be written uniquely as a linear combination of v_1, \dots , v_nv1,…,vnv_1, \dots , v_nv1​,…,vn​.

For instance, we have standard basis \{ e_1, \dots , e_n \}{e1,…,en}\{ e_1, \dots , e_n \}{e1​,…,en​} for \mathbb {F}^nFn\mathbb {F}^nFn, where e_ieie_iei​ is the vector with 1111 at iiii-th position and 0000 elsewhere.
Every spanning list in a vector space can be reduced to a basis.
From the theorem we can infer a corollary.
Every finite-dimensional vector space has a basis.
The next result states for a spanning list can be reduced to a basis. We can adjoin one or more vectors to a linearly independent list to form a basis.

frontmatter.title: Linearly dependent list extends to a basis

mainmatter.p: Every linearly independent list of vectors in a finite-dimensional vector space can be extended to a basis.
Remind the definition of direct sum, we can now show that every subspace of a finite-dimensional vecrtor space can be paired with another subspace to form a direct sum of the whole space.

frontmatter.title: Direct Sum of Subspaces of VVVV

mainmatter.p: Suppose VVVV is a finite dimensional vector space, and UUUU is a subspace of VVVV. Then there exists a subspace WWWW of VVVV such that V = U \oplus WV=U⊕WV = U \oplus WV=U⊕W.

This post discusses about finite-dimensional vector space. But we have not yet defined what is dimension. We tempted to define the dimension as the length of basis intuitively. With this definition we should prove its well-definedness. That is, every basis has the same length.
Let VVVV be a finite-dimensional vector space. Then every basis of VVVV has the same length.
This can be proved by Lemma 8. Now we can formally define the dimension of such spaces.
The dimension of a finite-dimensional vector space VVVV is the length of any basis of the vector space. Denoted by \dim Vdim⁡V\dim VdimV.
Every subspace of a finite-dimensional vector space is also finite-dimensional. Hence we can talk about the dimension of a subspace.
Let VVVV be a finite-dimensional vector space, and UUUU be a subspace of VVVV. Then \dim U \leq \dim Vdim⁡U≤dim⁡V\dim U \leq \dim VdimU≤dimV.

According to the definition of linearly independent, to show a list of vectors is a basis, we only need to show it is linearly independent, and it spans the whole space. The next theorems simplifies the task:

frontmatter.title: Linearly independent list of the right length is a basis

mainmatter.p: Let VVVV be a finite-dimensional vector space. Then every linearly independent list of vectors in VVVV with length equal to \dim Vdim⁡V\dim VdimV is a basis of VVVV.

frontmatter.title: Spanning list of the right length is a basis

mainmatter.p: Let VVVV be a finite-dimensional vector space. Then every spanning list of vectors in VVVV with length equal to \dim Vdim⁡V\dim VdimV is a basis of VVVV.
Now we move to the discussion of the dimension of the sum of two subspaces. This is analogous to the inclusion-exclusion principle.

Let VVVV be a finite-dimensional vector space, and UUUU and WWWW be subspaces of VVVV. Then \dim (U + W) = \dim U + \dim W - \dim (U \cap W). dim⁡(U+W)=dim⁡U+dim⁡W−dim⁡(U∩W). \dim (U + W) = \dim U + \dim W - \dim (U \cap W). dim(U+W)=dimU+dimW−dim(U∩W).
